channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Indian University Suspends Student Group Accused of Spreading Hatred Toward Modi
item.description: The left-wing student group that was accused of spreading hatred toward Prime Minister Narendra Modi, a university official said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Vitriol in the Media Adds Drama to Talks on Greek Bailout
item.description: Some analysts say sensationalism and obsessive coverage have made the negotiations more difficult.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Standoff Over Rescued Dogs in Northeast China
item.description: Dog traders, animal rights activists and the authorities have been negotiating for more than a week over control of nearly 500 dogs rescued from a truck stopped on a highway in northeast China.
item.dc:creator: CHERIE CHAN
item.media:credit: Jiandu Gonggong Shipin Weisheng Anquan Zhiyuanzhe Tuandui
item.media:description: The nearly 500 dogs were crammed into small cages on a truck before being rescued.

item.title: Loretta Lynch, With Assist From Soccer, Makes Strong Global Impression
item.description: Less than a month into her job as attorney general, Lynch captured the world’s attention when she vowed to rid FIFA, soccer’s governing body, of corruption.
item.dc:creator: MATT APUZZO and SAM BORDEN
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Loretta E. Lynch on Wednesday. Her news conference made her the face of the United States government’s crackdown on some of the world’s most influential soccer officials.

item.title: Great Barrier Reef Is Not ‘in Danger’ but Needs Care, U.N. Experts Say
item.description: A report cited climate change, water pollution and the impact of coastal development as major threats to the reef, a World Heritage site.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Irish Media Restrained in Reporting of Billionaire’s Dealings
item.description: A dispute between one of Ireland’s richest businessmen and its national broadcaster has raised questions about constraints on the country’s media.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: Sepp Blatter Re-elected as FIFA President
item.description: Mr. Blatter emerged from a week of scandal by drawing 133 votes on the first ballot, just short of the two-thirds majority required. His challenger, Prince Ali bin al-Hussein of Jordan, then withdrew.
item.category: Ali bin al-Hussein, Prince of Jordan
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Sepp Blatter after Prince Ali bin al-Hussein of Jordan withdrew from the FIFA presidential race. Mr. Blatter has held the position since 1998.

item.title: World Briefing: ISIS Claims Deadly Car Bombings at Baghdad Hotels
item.description: The bombings late Thursday night took place inside the parking lots within the tight security bubbles of two luxury hotels, killing 14 people.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Monitor in Ukraine Reports Seeing 4 in Russian Insignia Near Donetsk
item.description: The report by the Organization for Security and Cooperation was a rare allegation of a sighting of active Russian military personnel in eastern Ukraine.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Explosion Near Shiite Mosque Kills 4 in Eastern Saudi Arabia
item.description: It was the second attack claimed by the Islamic State in two weeks, and raises fears that sectarian passions fueling conflicts across the Middle East pose a threat to the kingdom.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: The site of an explosion near a Shiite mosque in Dammam, Saudi Arabia, on Friday.

item.title: At War Blog: After Divorce, Losing Veterans’ Support Along With a Spouse
item.description: Once you are divorced from a veteran, resources such as counseling go away, and many women who were dependent on their spouses’ incomes find themselves financially in shambles.
item.dc:creator: JACKIE MCMICHAEL

item.title: Talks on Asia’s Migration Crisis End With Plans to Target Root Causes
item.description: Delegates from more than 17 governments agreed to assist the strife-torn native areas of would-be migrants, as a boat with 727 people was found off Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: A camp for displaced people in Sittwe, Myanmar. More than 100,000 Rohingya in Myanmar live in camps, having been chased from their homes by mobs of radical Buddhists over the past three years.

item.title: U.S. Removes Cuba From State-Sponsored Terrorism List
item.description: The decision to remove Cuba from a list of state sponsors of terrorism is a crucial step in normalizing ties between Washington and Havana.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Raúl Castro and President Obama before a closed-door meeting at the Summit of the Americas in Panama City last month.

item.title: U.N. Resolves to Combat Plundering of Antiquities by ISIS
item.description: A resolution adopted unanimously by the General Assembly amounted to the broadest international condemnation so far to the cultural destruction wrought by the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Palestinian Soccer Association Drops Effort to Suspend Israel From FIFA
item.description: If approved, the move would have barred Israel from international competitions. A dispute over teams from settlements in the West Bank remained unresolved.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Patrick B. Kraemer/KEYSTONE, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jibril Rajoub, president of the Palestine Football Association, addresses delegates at FIFA's annual congress on Friday in Zurich.

item.title: Chinese Weapons Spotted on Disputed Island, U.S. Says
item.description: Artillery vehicles were seen on an artificial island the Chinese are building in the South China Sea, amid tensions between China and it neighbors.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Trial of Chinese Hotelier Features Accusations of Prostitution
item.description: Liang Yaohui became a multimillionaire before he was targeted in a crackdown on vice and was charged in a prostitution scandal.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and MIA LI

item.title: Water Revolution in Israel Overcomes Any Threat of Drought
item.description: A major national effort to desalinate Mediterranean seawater and to recycle wastewater has provided the country with enough water for all its needs.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Sorek desalination plant rises out of the sandy ground about nine miles south of Tel Aviv. Said to be the largest plant of its kind in the world, it produces 40 billion gallons of potable water a year, enough for about a sixth of Israel’s roughly eight million citizens.

item.title: Photographer Gets Prison Sentence for Swindling L’Oréal Heiress
item.description: François-Marie Banier was found guilty of “abuse of weakness” and money laundering. He was handed a three-year prison sentence with six months suspended.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: François-Marie Banier, a celebrity photographer, before hearing the court's verdict in Bordeaux, France, on Thursday.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Biracial Beauty Queen Strives for Change in Mono-Ethnic Japan
item.description: Ariana Miyamoto, the first half-black Miss Universe Japan, has endured slurs since she was a child. “Even today,” she said, “I am usually seen not as a Japanese but as a foreigner.”
item.dc:creator: MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ariana Miyamoto, Miss Universe Japan 2015, said she hoped to spotlight the difficulties that she and other mixed-race citizens face in Japan.
